The Australia National University,
as we all know but sometimes forget,

with the Indo-Pacific concept.

2642.20.text:
and I am a visiting fellow with
the National Security College.

2645.88.text:
I was very interested in
one of your earlier comments.

2649.24.text:
And that was that Australia requires
partnerships with other countries.

2655.72.text: So I'd like to ask you,

2658.80.text:
give you an opportunity to give us
some background on that

2664.76.text: and which countries do you think,

2666.56.text:
which countries in the region,
Indo-Pacific region,

2668.76.text:
do you think Australia
should develop partnerships with.

2672.00.text:
And I presume that you would
include Indonesia on this list.

2676.60.text:
And would you say that our
relationship with Indonesia

2679.88.text:
has been recently subject to
excessive populist pressures?

2686.96.text: -Rory Medcalf: Well where do I start?

2691.52.text:
Look, I won't focus very much on
the political issues you're referring to.

2697.44.text:
I don't think that's my
brief here this evening,

2700.72.text:
except that I'll say that of course
Indonesia is one of the countries

2704.20.text:
that we need to develop
as a security partner.

2705.96.text:
I did mention it, but I probably
buried it in a pretty,

2713.12.text:
I would rate Japan and India
above Indonesia in the near term

2719.00.text:
because these countries have really serious
strategic capabilities and interests.

2722.88.text: Indonesia's still trying to figure out,

2724.40.text:
in my view, what kind
of power it wants to be,

2727.08.text:
and indeed, whether it can exploit
its very strategic geography

2730.60.text: right in the middle of the Indo-Pacific,

2733.80.text:
whether it can actually use that
in an outward looking way.

2736.60.text:
And I don't think it's reached
that decision yet

2738.72.text:
despite some of the rhetoric
of the Indonesian president.

2742.36.text:
So Indonesia will be
one of those partners.

2744.92.text: And that's why we will need to continue

2746.96.text:
to work on that security
partnership with them.

2749.68.text:
But as I said, keeping a sense of
proportionality and self-respect,

2754.76.text:
and I suspect we're about
to come to one of those times

2757.28.text:
where the self-respect issue is going to be
pretty high on the agenda of both countries

2762.00.text:
and that will require serious
diplomacy on both sides.

2765.56.text:
One asset we have in the relationship
with Indonesia is the alumni,

2771.00.text:
not yet, sad to say,
students of the National Security College,

2774.76.text: but I hope that will change in the future,

2776.44.text:
but the defence officials and
defence officers, ADF officers,

2781.00.text:
who've served in Indonesia
over the years

2782.84.text:
and have developed very
close links at senior levels

2786.04.text:
with the Indonesian security community
and their counterparts here.

2789.28.text:
We need all these threads of
partnership to get this relationship

2793.16.text: through what will be another rocky patch.

2796.00.text:
But at a strategic level we have quite
convergent interests with Indonesia.

2800.28.text:
This idea of loose coalitions
in the region,

2804.08.text:
this idea of maritime
surveillance cooperation,

2806.36.text:
that's got Indonesia written all
over it if Indonesia's interested.

2813.40.text:
One thing that I guess it probably
depends on the timeline

2816.20.text:
you're looking at for
your review of security.

2819.96.text:
But one issue which I think
starts off being economic

2822.44.text:
but immediately turns into a security issue
that worries the Hell out of me,

2825.96.text:
not for me but for my children
or my grandchildren,

2828.56.text:
is perhaps we're approaching
a new industrial revolution

2833.20.text:
and the disappearance of work
as artificial intelligence,

2841.48.text:
And I just wondered if you think
that is a security issue

2847.88.text:
Look, I shouldn't laugh
because I know it's a serious,

2850.72.text:
it's a serious question
and I have kids too.

2853.72.text:
I wish they would work at the
moment [laughter] but that's,

2859.12.text: Look, looking at a fairly narrow sense,

2863.80.text:
there are, sad to say, advantages
for Australia in all of this,

2867.60.text: I mean we, you know, we should,

2869.20.text:
we should be embracing the unmanned
or autonomous revolution

2873.92.text: because it will actually suit us,

2875.68.text:
I think much better than
it will suit certain other countries

2878.48.text: in our region in the years ahead.

2880.40.text:
And then the flip side
of that is, of course,

2881.96.text:
how do you meaningful
fulfilling useful work for humans.

2886.20.text:
Look I'm not going to,
that's such a big area,

2889.16.text:
I'm really not going to go
there in any great depth.

2892.60.text:
You've got me
thinking about that tonight.

2895.24.text: But I think in the short term,

2896.28.text:
it's seen as beneficial
for security capabilities.

2900.48.text:
In the longer term, of course
it's got problems,

2902.24.text: particularly, not so much for us,

2904.16.text:
but for countries with
much larger populations,

2906.64.text:
that will have to deal with
social dissatisfaction,

2910.12.text:
that will have to deal with
unfulfilled expectations.

2913.24.text:
I think the bigger problem
is much shorter term.

2915.56.text: It's the next, in the next 20 years,

2917.48.text: it's whether the not middle classes

2919.72.text:
but the emerging classes in India, 
in China, in Indonesia

2924.48.text:
can find any kind of work
and any kind of education

2927.24.text: and I think that, to me,

2928.52.text:
will determine whether we
have a stable regional order

2931.64.text:
and I think we can worry a bit
about the future of work

2936.80.text:
But I'm going to
think about that one.

2943.20.text:
do you think we're reaching a point
in the domestic terrorist threat

2947.00.text: where the so-called lone wolf attacks really,

2950.76.text:
there's an element of impossibility in
disrupting and confronting these attacks

2954.56.text:
and whether the measures
to confront them

2958.04.text:
might have unacceptable
implications to privacy, etc.

2964.04.text: Now look, that's sort of the core question

2966.44.text: that I think needs to be properly debated

2969.48.text: by the critics of counter-terrorism measures

2971.60.text:
as well as by the supporters
of counter-terrorism measures.

2974.12.text:
And I think we just don't know yet
what the social implications of a much,

2979.08.text:
a significantly larger scale incident
then what occurred in Martin Place

2984.68.text:
There was fantastic mobilization of
community cohesion in showing solidarity,

2989.96.text:
particularly with Muslim Australians
around the incident.

2996.96.text:
It's quite conceivable that there
could be bigger and worse incidents

3001.48.text:
Just because it's extremely
difficult to prevent those incidents

3005.80.text: doesn't mean that we shouldn't try.

3008.16.text:
And I think no government
would survive not attempting

3012.04.text:
to prevent the next terrorist
incident or the one after it.

3015.20.text:
The last think you want
is any kind of vigilantism

3017.92.text:
which I guess is the alternative
to government action.

3021.80.text: But it's a debate worth having.

3025.56.text:
having read the review of the Joint
Parliamentary Committee on intelligence,

3031.20.text:
their review on metadata,
you know.

3033.80.text:
I think they're on the right track
and I even get the impression

3036.20.text:
that journalists are going
to begin to accept

3038.12.text: what comes out at the other end as well.

3040.12.text: But this will be a continual debate

3042.20.text:
and if we can have it on first
principles then I'm all for it.

3046.40.text:
-Ruth Pearce: Hello. 
Thank you very much.

3049.48.text:
I wanted to ask about your partners'
partners, multilateral...

3055.56.text:
Where does that fit in your
context of National Security.

3058.36.text: It just seems that, you know,

3062.24.text: there's ad hocery now, G20, etc.

3070.24.text:
-Rory Medcalf: You're lucky
Gareth Evans is not here

3071.60.text:
because he would've beaten you
to that question. [laughter]

3075.44.text:
And we wouldn't have been
able to say no.

3079.52.text:
I use very sparingly the term "pragmatic
multilateralism" at one point

3084.64.text: when I was referring to partnerships

3085.72.text: and I think the ideal outcome,

3087.08.text:
of course, is one where we
combine strong bilateralism,

3090.48.text:
the alliance, in my view,
minilateralism,

3098.36.text:
but most of the security problems
I can see in this survey

3102.64.text:
are not going to be solved
by the United Nations.

3107.48.text:
We can't somehow take
the UN out of that equation.

3111.64.text:
I think the mobilization
of our UN seat last year

3119.68.text:
I think the government
inherited something

3121.08.text: that it didn't particularly feel the need for

3122.84.text: and suddenly made very good use of it.

3125.24.text:
There will be more
opportunities like that,

3127.28.text: I am sure, in the future.

3128.20.text:
But I just don't think
UN global multilateralism

3131.60.text: is going to make much difference

3132.92.text:
in the regional security tensions
I'm talking about.

3135.56.text:
And then how many times have
we heard the UN Security Council

3137.76.text:
talk about the South China Sea or the
East China Sea in the past 5 years

3141.08.text:
when they've been moving
in the direction of flash points?

3145.56.text:
So I think we just need to
use that for norm building.

3148.36.text:
We need to build regional
multilateral institutions.

3151.16.text: I would put more priority there

3152.80.text:
and use that as a way
of setting informal rules

3157.28.text: But we just can't rely on these alone.

3159.64.text: And the credibility I talked about;

3165.28.text:
and maybe minilateral arrangements
for things like disaster relief

3170.64.text:
to then mobilize blocks and caucuses
within those multilateral organizations

3178.16.text:
that's what little joy I can offer you
on multilateralism.

3185.16.text: -Dr. Margot McCarthy: Well thank you Rory.

3186.24.text:
And thanks to members of the
audience for drawing Rory out

3192.60.text:
on some of the themes of his address
including the future of work.

3197.60.text: It was only a few months ago

3199.00.text:
that in this auditorium I was
thanking Rory's predecessor

3203.08.text:
for his efforts in starting up
the National Security College

3206.80.text:
and we were delighted that someone with
Rory's very distinguished background

3211.88.text:
in policy development,
analysis, and advocacy

3216.76.text:
was selected to build on
Michael's achievements.

3220.04.text:
And Rory's address tonight and
the discussion it's generated

3223.44.text:
has really only reinforced our
optimism about the value

3228.92.text:
between the Commonwealth
and the College.

3233.16.text:
When the idea of the college
was first promoted

3236.12.text: it was to enhance the capacity

3238.80.text:
of officials across
the national security community

3241.40.text:
and by that I don't think we just
mean the Commonwealth,

3245.00.text: but many of the people in this room,

3247.76.text:
to achieve whole of
government outcomes

3249.72.text:
and to lead cultural change 
in their own areas.

3253.68.text:
And what I particularly liked
about Rory's remarks tonight

3257.56.text:
was that while giving us a reasonable
mark on the whole of government front,

3264.20.text:
he was frank about how very
much more we have to do

3267.40.text: in the area of cultural change.

3270.64.text:
Because if you live and
breathe National Security,

3278.88.text: to pluck an example out if the air,

3281.44.text:
why the expenditure of
your committee of cabinet

3283.40.text: might not want to fund your good idea,

3286.36.text:
it can be usefully confronting
to have someone ask,

3290.64.text:
"Why do we even bother talking
about national security at all?"

3295.52.text:
It's even better to be forced to step
back from today's particular problem

3300.84.text:
and to reflect instead on
the wider national interests

3304.44.text:
that our labours are either
protecting or advancing.

3315.64.text:
and there are many high priests 
and priestesses with us tonight,

3323.08.text: to the very interests that we're striving

3325.12.text: to protect of insularity and complacency.

3333.68.text:
whether we're working on maximising
Australia's trade and investment interests

3348.00.text:
And I know I say on behalf
of many people here tonight,

3351.80.text:
how much we're looking forward
to working with you.
